cab.content: PART I.-ACTION TAKEN. ORDERS UNDER DEFENCE OF THE REALM REGULATIONS. The following Orders have been issued from the Ministry during the week : (1) The Pigs Control (Ireland) Order, 1918, dated 21 February, 1918, provides for the licensing and registration of buyers of pigs in Ireland. After the 1st March next it will be illegal for anyperson who has not applied to the Irish Committee for a certificate of registration under the Order, . and after the 15th March for any person who is not a holder of such. certificate of registration, to buy pigs in Ireland for slaughter; Registered buyers will receive an allocation of supplies on the basis of a period of normal trade and proper allocation will be made to English and Scottish buyers. (2) The Potatoes (Protection) Order, 1918, dated 21 February, 1918, enacts that every person who owns potatoes, or has potatoes in his possession or control shall at all times take reasonable precautions to protect them from frost, damp, or other damage, whether such potatoes are growing, in transit or in store, and that anyone who consigns potatoes for transport by railway in open trucks shall also take all necessary steps to protect them. (3) The Waste of Foodstuffs Order, 1918, dated 21 February, 1918, makes it an offence for a person to waste any foodstuffs or permit them to be wasted. An exception is made in the case of trade waste, not arising from want of due care, where the trader has been ready to sell foodstuffs at reasonable prices, and could not reasonably have made it available for human food otherwise than by way of sale. Any person authorised in writing by the Food Controller may enter premises where he has reason to believe that there is waste. (4) The Malt (Restriction) Order, 1918, dated 26 February, 1918, prohibits (except under licence) the manufacture, sale, purchase, delivery, or use of any malt or malt extract on and after the 1st March, 1918. An excep- tion is made of malt already in process of manufacture on February 28,, and also the use of malt under contract of delivery. It permits the purchase by a baker of malt for the purpose of making bread. (5) The Barley (Requisition) Order, 1918, dated 26th February, 1918, enables the Food Controller to requisition stocks of barley on 1st March, 1918. This refers to natural and kiln-dried, barley, both home-grown and imported. Returns giving full particulars of such stocks on the 1st March and contracts for sale of the same are to be sent to the Ministry of Food, not later than 7th March. The Order does not interfere with purchases by Controlled Flour Millers of barley not taken over under the Order. The Joint Orders Committee of the Board of Agriculture and the Ministry ofFood met on 26th February to discuss amendments in the Live Stock (Restriction ofSlaughter) Order and the Horses (Rationing) Order. There has been set up a Propaganda Committee consisting of two members of theBoard of Agriculture and two members of the Ministry of Food, for the purpose ofconducting a propaganda campaign throughout England and Wales with a view togiving special information to farmers on all Orders issued, publishing leaflets dealingwith such special points as the production of potatoes, preservation of the pigpopulation, and substitution of home-produced animal food to meet the shortage ofgrain and other feeding stuffs. ' * (33)4987-4 Pk 1 115 3/18 E & S A At a meeting of the Consumers' Council held at the Ministry of Food onWednesday, February 27th, the following resolutions were passed : (1) " That as a result of our consideration of the new Tea Order, we urge Lord Rhondda to abolish all rebates and to fix a flat rate to wholesalers and to retailers, allowing to the latter a gross profit of 3d. per lb. We also urge that inquiries should be made into.contract prices with tea-growers in India and Ceylon and into shipping freight, with a view to reducing the retail price from 2s. Sd. to 2s. Qd. a pound, this to be the only price." (2) " That in "the event of a serious shortage of a rationed food being ascertained, the Food Ministry should at once instruct and authorise the Distributing Authority in the various districts to guarantee to each person rationed an equal ration of such food, based upon the division of the smaller amount available." (3) " The Consumers' Council, having heard the statements Of Lord Crawford in support of the proposed Cakes and Pastry Order, re-affirms its previous resolution on the matter so far as the Order maybe made applicable to domestic cookery." . SUPPLIES AND PRICES. 'Allied Purchases, The following cable was sent by Lord Rhondda in reply to a cablegram from Lord Reading stating that the United States Railway Administration had undertaken to provide transportation from Chicago and other centres for about 40,000 tons of beef and packing-house products to the seaboard, but adding that the situation as regards shipment of cereals did not show much improvement.: " Food Controller desires to inform you that while all foods are of urgent - ii: importance the most vital foodstuff at the moment, providing cereals for shipment are short, is bacon, since this supplies both meat and fats. Food Controller is advised that quantity of bacon purchased but not shipped is over 100,000 tons, and he therefore trusts that special efforts will be made towards expediting deliveries of bacon." The United States Food Administration has informed Mr. Owen Smith that in addition to the 5,000 tons frozen beef authorised for purchase in the March pro- gramme, there will be available a further quantity of 20,000 tons steers, 3,000 tons cows and 4,500 tons boneless beef for delivery up to the middle of April. Mr. Owen Smith cables that the United States Food Administration state they are now able to relax the prohibition of the export of cotton-seed oil and that the position as regards lard substitutes, lard, and also margarine is easier. . This will enable the Allies to increase their purchases of these articles. Mr. Owen Smith cables that in addition to purchases on Government account, all possible private shipments in accordance with priority, and such other food products as are quickly available at New York and other American ports are being shipped and that no ocean space is being missed so long as Government- or private food purchases can be secured to fill it. He has already purchased sufficient meats, fats, and oils in America to fill the 180,000 tons of space allotted by the Ministry of Shipping for the month of March, and more supplies are available. Bacon, Hams, and Lard. Arrangements have been made to meet all anticipated requirements of the London and Home Counties Rationing Scheme, and the supply of bacon should bs ample. A special reserve of 800 boxes is being held by certain wholesalers to meet any emergency which may arise. The proposal that Irish production should be first used to satisfy Irish require- ments, the surplus only being exported to Great Britain, which was mentioned in the last Report, has made further progress. Concrete proposals have been laid before the Food Control Committee for Ireland, and if, as is probable, the proposals are accepted, not only will the waste of the present system of imports - of ' Irish - bacon from Ireland and export of American bacon from Great Britain to Ireland be avoided, but the problem of distribution in Great Britain will be considerably simplified, as the imported North American bacon wholly under the control of the Ministry of Food will be. a very great proportion of the total sxxpplies in Great Britain. Butter.-The statement made last week with regard to the purchase of 500 tons of Danish butter at 312s. per cwt. landed, should have referred to Dutch butter; no Danish butter was purchased last week. A further purchase of 60 tons, of butter at prices ranging from 44 to 48 cents f.a.s. New York has been made in the United States.of America, and a further 16 tons at 391- cents has been purchased in Canada. Steps are being taken to acquireabout 900 tons of butter available in Denmark, for shipment to this country; it isexpected that the price will be approximately 610s. c.i.f.: : About 17,500 tons of butter are now on the water. : Cheese-The quantity of New Zealand cheese "now oh the way to this countryis 6,953 tons, of which, 5,000 tons is expected in March and 1,953 in April. Thearrival of 1,532 tons of Old Season Canadian Cheese is expected within the first halfof March, and 674 tons still remain to be shipped. 1*500 tons of cheese have beenallotted to the Ministry of Food by the United States of America Food Administration,and;it is hoped to complete the February allotment shortly. The distribution of cheese to the civilian population which was begun last week,is: nearly completed; Cocoa. Instructions have been sent to Mr. Owen Smith to secure the shipmentof: some 1,200 tons Of loose Cocoa; powder now lying in New York, which has beenpurchased by firms in this country. Mr. Owen Smith has been instructed to buy thisquantity if he can at did. per lb., and, in any case, to make arrangements for itsexport. Cold. Storage. Mr. Brickwell, formerly Chief Surveyor to the Great NorthernRailway Has been appointed Director'of the Cold Storage Section, in succession toMr. J. Wardle. ' Dried Fruits.: The s.s. " Rooke " sailed from Patras with 1,000 tons of currantson February 20th. :. The s.s. " Cadagua " has been chartered, and wall sail from Spain on March 10thfor a Bristol Channel port. 1,375 tons of Malaga raisins have been purchased atslightly; under 40s. f.o.b., and an option obtained for a further 200 tons in case the" Cadagua " will take deck cargo. The cost of the raisins will thus - be just under60s. c.i.f. Fruit Supplies and, Preservation.-.91,000 half-chests.of Spanish bitter orangeshave been landed in this, country.up to date. Shipments of Sicilian bitter orangeshave not yet been delivered. Notification has been received that 1,000,000 bee sections are awaiting shipmentfrom the United States. The fruit pulp laid down by the Ministry during last season is being sent tocertain firms for making jam, for despatch to various centres where there is a shortage.Buildings for prospective fruit pulping'stations have been surveyed in various,townsin the fruit-growing centres. Arrangements are being made with the War Office totake over their pulping factories at Evesham. and Wisbech; Meat.- The position during the past Aveek has been distinguished by the intro-duction of rationing in the London and Some Counties area. It is already evident thatconsiderable changes will he effected in the consumption of meat, and it is possiblethat experience will show some modifications of the original scheme to be desirable. - ' The tendency at present is for the consumer to delay purchases untilthe end ofthe week, with the result that more than sufficient meat has been placed on themarket, in the early days of the, week and offal has been entirely neglected. In orderto prevent waste of such a perishable article as offal, a concession has been made fora period of one week, enabling restaurants and eating-houses to utilise: this offal without requiring coupons from the public. ' - The standard of approximately 1. lb. per head in the London rationing area hasnot.unnaturally created some dissatisfaction in those areas where the reduction ofconsumption to 50 per cent, of! the October standard brought the figure to much lessthan 1 lb. per head. It is assumed as a matter of course that if 1 lb. can be providedfor London and Home Counties other areas are entitled to the same standard. ' -- There are, also very strong demands for an addition to the ration for. those engaged on heavy manual labour, and the Food Controller has promised that as soon as rationing is1' universal'and the supplies permit' this additional ration shall'be regarded as a first charge on the additional supply. Some "-difficulties are being experienced in connection with the importers of Irish .. cattle. The special channels of trade which have been established for the conduct of this business in the past are not proving very amenable to the system'cf control which is necessary. One result is that the meat supply in Lancashire at the-present time is deficient, and a number of the large towns are practically dependent upon frozen; meah rThe reserve stocks, of frozen meat have not yet reached a figure which\ wo aid-provide any. large, measure of safety as: compared with, the-terms.-of consumptionunder the. rationing, scheme, but North America is still.able to offer,meat very freelyand the only obstacle in the way of getting more ample;.supplies from the usualsources is the limitation of refrigerated : tonnage. The killings of, home-grown stockhave not yet increased to the level required for the purposes of the rationing scheme,and the upward movement of the curve is very slow indeed. This season of the yearis, however, the one at which the numbers of beasts ready for slaughter are always attheir lowest. ' The change from the method of selling cattle and sheep on a live weight, basisto a dead weight basis is being proceeded with gradually, and has as yet beenadopted only in few districts. It is not intended that the dead weight basis shallentirely supersede the present system of grading or estimate of weight, as this appearsto be the more suitable to conditions in some parts of the country. Oils and Fats.--During the week ending, February 24th the output of home-produced margarine reached the record amount of 5,115 tons, 5,077 tons being thelargest amount previously produced in any one week. The question of includingedible oils for cooking purposes in the present ration of butter and margarine is beingconsidered. Sugar. The Food Controller, after consultation with the Royal Commission onthe Sugar Supply, has announced that, so far as the position can at present beforeseen, it will be possible to allocate approximately 10,000 tons of sugar during thecoming fruit season to enable private fruit-growers to convert their own fruit into jam,without reducing the issue required to supply fully the jam manufacturers who servethe bulk of the urban and industrial population. Tea. The Food Control Committee for Ireland has fixed the 15th April as theappointed day under clause 6 of the Tea (Prices) Order, 1918, on and after which themaximum retail price of all tea shall be at a rate of 2s. Sd. a pound. Food Control Committees in Great Britain have been advised that a fortnightsextension from the dates named.in the clause may be advisable to avoid hardship toretailers, but that in no case should the postponement be greater than three weeks. Vegetable Preservation.-Owmg to the restrictions placed, on the textile tradesthe actual demand for farina is estimated not to exceed 25,000 tons. Arrangementsfor the manufacture of this quantity in factories situated in the potato-growingdistricts are under consideration. The consumption of farina in the textile trade willrelease a corresponding quantity of rice and maize. The policy decided on in regard to setting up plants for the manufacture ofpotato flour has been settled on the lines that these plants shall be placed in thecentre of the principal potato-growing districts rather than in the larger towns, so asto minimise transport difficulties as it is easier to convey the dried product ratherthan the heavy raw material. The delivery of the first units of the machinery isbeing pressed forward acs fast as possible. Attention is being given to the question of preparing sliced and dried potatoes,and experiments have resulted in satisfactory products. Vegetable Supplies. In order to assist the importation of Irish potatoes intoGreat Britain, committees have been formed in Ireland and in South Wales to carryout their importation and distribution, and to prevent the flow of English potatoesinto South Wales, an Order has been issued forbidding the transport of potatoes fromother areas. Shipping facilities have been provided for the cross-Channel traffic, andthe importation of potatoes from Ireland has become sufficient to enable theirdistribution to be extended to the South-Western counties. DISTRIBUTION AND ENFORCEMENT. Food Control Committees. In the past week sanction has been given to 28 com-mittees to increase their representation of labour. The increase already allowed hasled in Lancashire to a better understanding between the committees and labour; andmuch good has followed the efforts of the labour representatives to explain thedifficulties with which the committees have to contend. Distribution.-A conference attended by all the Food Commissioners was held onthe 21st to discuss rationing schemes and methods of food distribution. The London and Home Counties Rationing Scheme has. definitely started, andthere appears to have been comparatively little-friction or serious trouble in spite of the great difficulties experienced in meeting the demands madron the printers for thelarge supply of forms required. , \. , . The large consumption of food in the Y.M.C.A. and'other canteens continues toexcite remark. It is estimated that the total number of persons rationed for butter and margarineunder all the rationing schemes in force now amounts to 27,000,000. There has been a decided improvement in the situation as regards queues, whichhave in many places practically disappeared. In some towns they are reported tohave been most noticeable outside pork butchers' shops, and in Leicester it waafound advisable to close these shops in consequence, and to make over the supplies tomeat butchers and grocers. The Corporation of Glasgow are taking immediate steps to establish two largekitchens. The interest in this movement appears to be growing. Enforcement. For the week ending the 16th February returns have beenreceived of 658 prosecutions in England, Wales, and Scotland, of which 577 resultedin convictions. 1 The average fine was SI. 4s. lid. A notable feature is the increase to 77 in the number of prosecutions forinfringement of the Orders affecting meat. There were also 65 prosecutions in con-nection with the Butter Orders, and 52 for Hoarding. Of these last, 17 wereunsuccessful. PART II.-SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION. . The supplies so far as imports are concerned, though lower, approximate tothe more satisfactory level reached in the previous week. As will be seen from theensuing paragraphs and Table A. wheat and flour show a considerable advance, andin this respect February compares favourably with January. On the other hand,, itmust be pointed out that circumstances have reduced the stock of cereals below whatwas anticipated when the cereal year began. Moreover, the full effect of the meatshortage on the consumption of bread remains to be seen. The meat supply still gives rise to anxiety. As compared with the same periodin last year, home-fed meat has fallen off markedly and little improvement can beanticipated for some time. Hence the necessity for reduced consumption, which canbe attained only by rationing. With this in prospect and with the supplies ofbutter, margarine, and cheese still very low, the next two months cannotbut bedifficult. On the other hand, there is an appearance of improvement in the baconposition, while in the case of tea both stocks and supplies have increasedconsiderably. . IMPORTS. Aggregate imports of principal foods were 173,270 tons in the week endingFebruary 23rd (Table A); this total fails to-reach the fairly satisfactory level of181,000 tons of the week February 10th-16th, but it is well above all other weeksthis year. " . . x 4987-4 ' ] u ': 56,400 tons of wheat and 35,100 tons of flour arrived. To find so large a weekly-import, we have to turn, back to the 2nd week in September when the receipt of75,900 tons of wheat and 22,000 tons of' flour was recorded. This week's importsare, however, only equal to the average necessary for the rest of the cereal year, if thereserve of 13 weeks supply is maintained. Imports of other cereals were 29,000 tonsbelow the level of the previous, week, which included a specially large consignmentof rice. The imports of oats has again fallen to a very low figure. Some improvement in imports of meat and a considerable increase in imports ofbacon, ham, and lard is shown. Together these amounted to 24,500 tons, which isabove the average weekly imports of the pre-war year 1913, viz.. "23,000 tons. Therehas. been some increase in margarine and butter. There is a fall in the imports of sugar while those of tea have improved. CONSUMPTION.
